description: Areas that are within 1/2 mile of a Major Transit stop , defined as any of the following:- Existing rail stations- Planned rail stations in an adopted RTP- Existing ferry terminals with bus or rail service- Planned ferry terminals with bus or rail service in an adopted RTP- Intersection of at least two existing or planned bus routes with headways of 15 minutes or better during both the morning and evening peak periods
primary_uses: UrbanSim Modeling; Regional Growth Framework; Plan Bay Area

description: These are secondary housing units that are built on an existing single family residential lot.  These units are attached (owned) by the same property owner of the single family dwelling. (Can be calculated based upon jurisdiction housing policies).

description: The location, and affordability restrictions if applicable, of housing developments for which permits have been issued, for 2014 through 2017, in order to track progress toward housing production goals and to support analysis and policy development. This data contains the building permit attributes. The features (point) need to be downloaded separately. These attributes will need to be joined to the features for mapping and spatial analysis.
primary_uses: Housing Program; Residential Development Tracking; CASA

description:
Tracks potential or designated locations where future housing may be built.  These locations are designated by local jurisdictions and collected by the housing team to track Regional Housing Need Assessment (RHNA) progress.

The site list was compiled from the housing opportunity sites inventories prepared by each of the region’s 101 cities and nine counties as part of the 2007-2014 and 2015-2023 RHNA housing element cycles.
primary_uses: Housing Program; Residential Development Tracking; CASA

description: An inventory of housing related policies adopted by local jurisdictions.
primary_uses: Housing Program; Residential Development Tracking; CASA

description: Units designated for preservation by local jurisdictions.
primary_uses: Housing Program; Residential Development Tracking; CASA

description: This represents affordable housing units, it includes a database of current housing with low income residency requirements.
primary_uses: Used as an input to UrbanSim; reflected in land use forecasts and used in travel forecasts for the RTP/SCS, TIP, STIP, etc.

description: Commonly known as PDAs, these are the current areas, within existing communities, that local jurisdictions have identified and approved for future housing and job growth in the community.  These areas form the foundation for sustainable growth for Plan Bay Area.
primary_uses: UrbanSim Modeling; Regional Growth Framework; Plan Bay Area

description: This feature set contains the Alquist-Priolo Earthquake Fault Zones and fault traces, as shown on the Revised Official Alquist-Priolo Earthquake Fault Zones Map, for the San Francisco Bay Region.
primary_uses: Resiliance Programs; UrbanSim Modeling; Plan Bay Area

description: Features represent Fire Hazard Severity Zones, in State Responsibility Areas, developed by the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection (Cal Fire). The features are a subset of a statewide feature set that was clipped to the San Francisco Bay Region. It was used for hazard analysis conducted for the Plan Bay Area 2040 Environmental Impact Report.
primary_uses: Resiliance Programs; UrbanSim Modeling; Plan Bay Area
source: California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection (CAL FIRE)

description: Debris flow source areas for rainfall/storm induced landslides
primary_uses: Resiliance Programs; UrbanSim Modeling; Plan Bay Area

description:
This data provides a summary of the distribution of landslides evident in the landscape of the San Francisco Bay Region. In general, landslide maps are now available for most of the region at scales of 1:24,000 – 1:62,500. The method of compilation and resolution of 1:125,000 (1 inch = 2 miles) limits use of this data to regional considerations. For more detailed information, reference the original 1:24,000 - 1:62,500 maps, if available in local libraries, or consult local officials or private consultants.

This version is maintained separately from the Plan Bay Area 2040 EIR version in case the source provider makes an update available.
primary_uses: Resiliance Programs; UrbanSim Modeling; Plan Bay Area

data_set: Federal Emergency Management Agency Flood Zones
description:
Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) flood zone feature set, from the National Flood Hazard Layer, for the San Francisco Bay Region. The data includes every county in the region except the City & County of San Francisco. This flood zone data was part of the hazard analysis conducted for the Plan Bay Area 2040 Environmental Impact Report. This flood zone data should not be used for flood insurance purposes, but rather hazard mapping. Flood Insurance Rate Map (FIRM) data retrieved directly from FEMA should be used for insurance programs.

This version is maintained separately from the Plan Bay Area 2040 EIR version as the data has been updated by the data provider and it what is currently in use for mapping and analysis at MTC/ABAG.
primary_uses: Resiliance Programs; UrbanSim Modeling; Plan Bay Area

description: Extents of previous wildfires in the San Francisco Bay Area
primary_uses: Resiliance Programs; UrbanSim Modeling; Plan Bay Area
source: California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection (CAL FIRE)

description: Earthquake induced landslide hazard areas mapped by the California Geological Survey
primary_uses: Resiliance Programs; UrbanSim Modeling; Plan Bay Area

description: Liquefaction hazard areas mapped by the California Geological Survey
primary_uses: Resiliance Programs; UrbanSim Modeling; Plan Bay Area

description:
This data set represents the entire San Francisco Bay Region by combining both Open-File Report 00-444 and Open-File Report 2006-1037 data. The area covered by Open-File Report 2006-1037 was erased from Open-File Report 00-444 and the two data sets were merged. A column has been added to the attribute table to label which report each polygon was originally from. The data presents Quaternary deposits and liquefaction susceptibility for the nine-county San Francisco Bay Region. The nine counties surrounding San Francisco Bay straddle the San Andreas fault system, which exposes the region to serious earthquake hazard (Working Group on California Earthquake Probabilities, 1999). Much of the land adjacent to the Bay and the major rivers and streams is underlain by unconsolidated deposits that are particularly vulnerable to earthquake shaking and liquefaction of water-saturated granular sediment.

This version is maintained separately from the Plan Bay Area 2040 EIR version in case the source provider makes an update available.
primary_uses: Resiliance Programs; UrbanSim Modeling; Plan Bay Area

data_set: NOAA 2ft Sea Level Rise Scenario for the San Francisco Bay Region
description:
This feature set is an sea level rise scenario, for the San Francisco Bay Region, produced by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). The scenario was produced using a projected two foot sea level rise and includes both open water rise and inland inundation.

This version is maintained separately from the Plan Bay Area 2040 EIR version as the data has been updated by the data provider and it what is currently in use for mapping and analysis at MTC/ABAG.
primary_uses: Resiliance Programs; UrbanSim Modeling; Plan Bay Area

data_set: NOAA 2ft Sea Level Rise Scenario for the San Francisco Bay Region: Low-Lying Areas
description:
This feature set, related to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's (NOAA) two foot sea level rise scenario for the San Francisco Bay Region, represents the low-lying areas vulnerable to inundation due to their proximity to areas expected to flood. The low-lying areas take into account the hydroconnectivity of inundated areas, which distinguishes it from a simple bathtub (static) approach. In addition, the feature set also shows low-lying areas, which are considered hydrologically “unconnected” areas that may flood, such as low-lying areas protected by levees.

This version is maintained separately from the Plan Bay Area 2040 EIR version as the data has been updated by the data provider and it what is currently in use for mapping and analysis at MTC/ABAG.
primary_uses: Resiliance Programs; UrbanSim Modeling; Plan Bay Area

description:
This data set shows likely shaking intensity in the San Francisco Bay Area in any 50 year period from all possible faults. It is an equivalent risk to a 500 year flood event. A 10% in 50 years probability was chosen as it most closely aligns with current building standards in the California Building Code. The data set is not intended to be site-specific. Rather, it depicts the general risk within neighborhoods and the relative risk from community to community. It was developed in conjunction with the United States Geological Survey (USGS) and California Geological Survey (CGS) by determining Probabilistic Seismic Hazard Assessment for Peak Ground Velocity (PGV) for 52,961 points along a grid covering the entire Bay Area, at intervals of 0.05 degrees longitude and 0.05 degrees latitude. PGV was then converted to the Modified Mercalli Intensity (MMI) measure. This analysis incorporates soil conditions which affect the velocity of ground shaking.

This version is maintained separately from the Plan Bay Area 2040 EIR version in case the source provider makes an update available.
primary_uses: Resiliance Programs; UrbanSim Modeling; Plan Bay Area
source: Association of Bay Area Governments, California Geologic Survey, CalTech Seismological Laboratory, Berkeley Seismological Laboratory, United States Geological Survey - Menlo Park, United States Geological Survey - Pasadena, and the California Governor's Office of Emergency Services

description: Locations along shorelines where inundation is expected to rise due to global warming. Feature set displays potential sea level rise inundation ranging from 1 to 6 feet above current Mean Higher High Water (MHHW) for the San Francisco Bay Region.
primary_uses: Resiliance Programs; UrbanSim Modeling; Plan Bay Area

description: Projected intensities from shaking scenarios generated for the San Francsico Bay Region by the US Geological Survey.
primary_uses: Resiliance Programs; UrbanSim Modeling; Plan Bay Area

Data was developed by the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection (Cal Fire).

Includes Historic and Commercial Bldgs. (basis)

description: Includes major projects, and residential development. Is comprised of a list of building projects recently completed, under construction, or approved

description: Most of the information that goes into the land use forecast comes from the data in the basemap, the pipeline, and the forecast of market-rate development built by the UrbanSim Developer Model. However, large institutions often operate outside of the market, are unlikely to move, and are likely to expand operations at their current location. Examples of this include UC Berkeley, Cupertino City Hall, and Highland Hospital. Many of these entities also operate group quarters so all group quarter forecasting is also part of this database.
primary_uses: UrbanSim Modeling
data_steward_notes: Ad hoc representation in parcel database

description: Locations, structures or features of a landscape or town that have importance to a community or makes a place easily recognizable.
primary_uses: UrbanSim Modeling

description: The parcel/building data includes the unique parcel identifier (APN) as well as attributes about the parcel (county, land value, if the parcel can’t be developed) and buildings (year assessed, square feet, number of stories, if the building is historic). (basis)
primary_uses: UrbanSim Modeling

description: Development Policies are laws, rules, processes, fees, and subsidies that impact private sector real estate development. Common policies for a parcel or neighborhood might limit uses (e.g., no commercial uses allowed), set maximum intensities (e.g., no more than 10 dwelling units per acre), require multiple project approvals, or assess fees on construction. All together, these policies influence project feasibility at a site to the extent that profitable projects may become unprofitable and vice versa. In this way they play a major role in determining the future trajectory of Bay Area neighborhoods.
primary_uses: UrbanSim Modeling

description: Land Use Policies designated by local jurisdictions to manage future development and growth within their respective jurisdictions.
primary_uses: UrbanSim Modeling, Regional Planning and Policy, Housing Programs, CASA

description: Sites designated by local jurisdictions where development cannot occur.  (These sites can be determined based upon bldg. type)

description: A specific plan is a tool for the systematic implementation of a jurisdictions general plan. It effectively establishes a link between implementing policies of the general plan and the individual development proposals in a defined area.
primary_uses: UrbanSim Modeling
data_steward_notes: Not collected except for one or two cities.

description: An Urban Growth Boundary is a regional boundary, set in an attempt to control urban sprawl by, in its simplest form, mandating that the area inside the boundary be used for urban development and the area outside be preserved in its natural state or used for agriculture.
primary_uses: UrbanSim Modeling, Regional Planning and Policy, Housing Programs

description: Land Use policies designated by local jurisdictions to manage and control existing development and intensity of use of land within the current jurisdiction limits.

data_set: San Francisco Bay Region Spheres of Influence
description: The California Association Local Agency Formation Commissions defines a sphere of influence (SOI) as "a planning boundary outside of an agency’s legal boundary (such as the city limit line) that designates the agency’s probable future boundary and service area." This feature set represents the SOIs of the incorporated jurisdictions for the San Francisco Bay Region. San Francisco is not included because, as both a city and county, it does not have an SOI.
primary_uses: TBD

data_set: Adapting to Rising Tides: 2ft Sea Level Rise Scenario
description: This feature set is a subset of the regional data produced for the San Francisco Bay Conservation and Development's (BCDC) Adapting to Rising Tides project. The subset contains projected inundation extents for Alameda, Contra Costa, Marin, San Francisco, and San Mateo counties for a two-foot rise in sea level associated with climate change. The two-foot sea level rise scenario represents the high end of the level of increase expected by 2050. This feature set was used for hazard analysis conducted for the Plan Bay Area 2040 Environmental Impact Report.
primary_uses: Resiliance Programs; UrbanSim Modeling; Plan Bay Area
source: San Francisco Bay Conservation and Development Commission

data_set: Adapting to Rising Tides: 2ft Sea Level Rise Scenario – Low-Lying Areas
description: Hydraulically disconnected low-lying areas for a subset of the regional inundation modeling conducted by the San Francisco Bay Conservation and Development Commission for its Adapting to Rising Tides project. The subset contains hydraulically disconnected low-lying areas for Alameda, Contra Costa, Marin, San Francisco, and San Mateo counties associated with a two-foot sea level rise scenario. This feature set was used for hazard analysis conducted for the Plan Bay Area 2040 Environmental Impact Report.
primary_uses: Resiliance Programs; UrbanSim Modeling; Plan Bay Area
source: San Francisco Bay Conservation and Development Commission

description:
The California Protected Areas Database (CPAD) inventories open space lands that have been protected for open space uses through fee ownerships. CPAD is not a database of all public lands – for example, it does not include public buildings, water treatment sites, or other non-open space public land. Check https://www.calands.org/cpad/ for the latest version.

This version is maintained separately from the Plan Bay Area 2040 EIR version as the data has been updated by the data provider and it what is currently in use for mapping and analysis at MTC/ABAG.

data_set: Critical Habitat for Threatened and Endangered Species (line)
description: When a species is proposed for listing as endangered or threatened under the Endangered Species Act, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS) must consider whether there are areas of habitat believed to be essential for species conservation. Those areas may be proposed for designation as critical habitat. Critical habitat is a term defined and used in the Act. It is a specific geographic area(s) that contains features essential for the conservation of a threatened or endangered species and that may require special management and protection. Critical habitat may include an area that is not currently occupied by the species but that will be needed for its recovery. An area is designated as critical habitat after the USFWS publishes a proposed Federal regulation in the Federal Register and receives and considers public comments on the proposal. The final boundaries of the critical habitat are also published in the Federal Register.
primary_uses: UrbanSim Modeling; Plan Bay Area
source: United States Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS)

data_set: Critical Habitat for Threatened and Endangered Species (polygon)
description: When a species is proposed for listing as endangered or threatened under the Endangered Species Act, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS) must consider whether there are areas of habitat believed to be essential for species conservation. Those areas may be proposed for designation as critical habitat. Critical habitat is a term defined and used in the Act. It is a specific geographic area(s) that contains features essential for the conservation of a threatened or endangered species and that may require special management and protection. Critical habitat may include an area that is not currently occupied by the species but that will be needed for its recovery. An area is designated as critical habitat after the USFWS publishes a proposed Federal regulation in the Federal Register and receives and considers public comments on the proposal. The final boundaries of the critical habitat are also published in the Federal Register.
primary_uses: UrbanSim Modeling; Plan Bay Area
source: United States Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS)

description:
The California Department of Transportation (Caltrans) and California Department of Fish and Wildlife (CDFW) commissioned the California Essential Habitat Connectivity Project because a functional network of connected wildlands is essential to the continued support of California's diverse natural communities in the face of human development and climate change. The Essential Connectivity data depicts large, relatively natural habitat blocks that support native biodiversity (Natural Landscape Blocks) and areas essential for ecological connectivity between them (Essential Connectivity Areas). Each Essential Connectivity Area serves to connect at least two, and as many as 15, Natural Landscape Blocks. This coarse-scale data was based primarily on the concept of ecological integrity, rather than the needs of particular species.

This version is maintained separately from the Plan Bay Area 2040 EIR version as the data has been updated by the data provider and it what is currently in use for mapping and analysis at MTC/ABAG.
primary_uses: UrbanSim Modeling; Plan Bay Area
source: California Department of Fish and Wildlife

description:
Forest land, from the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA), for the San Francisco Bay Region and surrounding counties. Forest areas are a subset of the USDA's 2011 California Cropland Data Layer (CDL). Feature set was used in the Plan Bay Area 2040 Environmental Impact Report analysis. The 2011 CDL has a ground resolution of 30 meters. The CDL is produced using satellite imagery from the Landsat 5 TM sensor, Landsat 7 ETM+ sensor, the Spanish DEIMOS-1 sensor, the British UK-DMC 2 sensor, and the Indian Remote Sensing RESOURCESAT-1 (IRS-P6) Advanced Wide Field Sensor (AWiFS) collected during the current growing season.

This version is maintained separately from the Plan Bay Area 2040 EIR version as the data has been updated by the data provider and it what is currently in use for mapping and analysis at MTC/ABAG.
primary_uses: UrbanSim Modeling; Plan Bay Area

description:
Steelhead Salmon, listed by Federal Government as a threatened species, critical habitat in the San Francisco Bay Region. This feature set was acquired from the California Department of Fish and Wildlife (CDFW), but the National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) was the data originator.

This version is maintained separately from the Plan Bay Area 2040 EIR version in case the source provider makes an update available.
primary_uses: TBD

description: Ultramafic rock deposits in the San Francsico Bay Region. Ultramafic rock is chiefly composed of mafic minerals (rich in iron and magnesium), and less than about 45 percent silica, such as olivine, augite, or hypersthene. Pyroxene and serpentinite are ultramafic rocks. Ultramafic rock commonly contains chrysotile and amphibole asbestos. Asbestos is a known carcinogen and inhalation of asbestos may result in development of lung cancer or mesothelioma. The California Air Resources Board (CARB) has regulated the amount of asbestos in crushed serpentinite used in surfacing applications, such as for gravel on unpaved roads, since 1990. In 1998, new concerns were raised about possible health hazards from activities that disturb rocks and soil containing asbestos and may generate asbestos-laden dust. These concerns recently lead to CARB to revise their asbestos limit for crushed serpentinite and ultramafic rock in surfacing applications from five percent to less than 0.25 percent, and to adopt a new rule requiring best practices dust control measures for activities that disturb rock and soil (construction projects are one example) containing naturally occurring asbestos.
primary_uses: Resiliance Programs; UrbanSim Modeling; Plan Bay Area

data_set: Wetlands in the San Francisco Bay Region and Surrounding Counties
description: This data set represents the extent, approximate location and type of wetlands and deepwater habitats in the San Francisco Bay Region (extracted from a larger data set of the United States and its territories). These data delineate the areal extent of wetlands and surface waters as defined by Cowardin et al. (1979). The National Wetlands Inventory - Version 2, Surface Waters and Wetlands Inventory was derived by retaining the wetland and deepwater polygons that compose the NWI digital wetlands spatial data layer and reintroducing any linear wetland or surface water features that were orphaned from the original NWI hard copy maps by converting them to narrow polygonal features. Additionally, the data are supplemented with hydrography data, buffered to become polygonal features, as a secondary source for any single-line stream features not mapped by the NWI and to complete segmented connections.
primary_uses: UrbanSim Modeling; Plan Bay Area
source: United States Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS)

data_set: Farmland Mapping and Monitoring Program Data
description:
Established in 1982, Government Code Section 65570 mandates the FMMP biennially report on the conversion of farmland and grazing land, and to provide maps and data to local government and the public. The data is an inventory of agricultural resources used for general planning purposes and has a minimum mapping unit of ten acres.

This version is maintained separately from the Plan Bay Area 2040 EIR version as the data has been updated by the data provider and it what is currently in use for mapping and analysis at MTC/ABAG.
primary_uses: UrbanSim Modeling; Plan Bay Area
source: California Department of Conservation, Farmland Mapping and Monitoring Program

data_set: San Francisco Bay Conservation and Development Commission Priority Use Areas
description: Priority Use Areas are one of the tools used by the San Francisco Bay Conservation and Development Commission (BCDC) to manage the health and use of San Francisco Bay (Bay). The purpose of the Priority Use Areas is to balance the region's economic, recreation, and conservation needs. While local jurisdictions have authority to propose and implement development along Bay shorelines, projects proposed for the shoreline require a permit from BCDC as its authority extends 100 feet inland from the Bay shoreline's mean high tide line. Priority Use Areas are for shoreline uses that are important to the region, suited for water-oriented uses, and require a shoreline location. They include, but are not limited to, airports, ports, water-related industry, wildlife refuges, and waterfront parks and beaches. Shoreline areas are designated as Priority Use Areas in order to minimize the need to fill the Bay if land is unavailable for those uses.
primary_uses: UrbanSim Modeling; Plan Bay Area
source: San Francisco Bay Conservation and Development Commission

description: The location, and affordability restrictions if applicable, of housing developments for which permits have been issued, for 2014 through 2017, in order to track progress toward housing production goals and to support analysis and policy development.
